any provision of nuclear regulations identified in accordance with section 58(10) (requirement for provisions made for nuclear security purposes or nuclear safeguards purposes, or both, to be identified as such), or

P3para.Text: any condition attached to a nuclear site licence under section 4 of the Nuclear Installations Act 1965 relating to a site in England, Wales or Scotland.

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies where an inspector is of the opinion that—

P3para.Text: relevant activities, as they are being carried on by or under the control of a person, involve a risk of serious personal injury, or
relevant activities which are likely to be carried on by or under the control of a person will, as so carried on, involve a risk of serious personal injury.

P2para.Text: The inspector may, if authorised, give the person a notice (“a prohibition notice”) directing that the activities to which the notice relates must not be
carried on by or under the control of the person unless the following have been remedied—

P3para.Text: the matters specified in the notice under sub-paragraph (3)(b), and
any associated contraventions of provisions specified under sub-paragraph (3)(c).

P2para.Text: A prohibition notice must—

P3para.Text: state that the inspector is of the opinion mentioned in sub-paragraph (1);
specify the matters which in the inspector’s opinion give, or, as the case may be, will give rise to the risk mentioned in that sub-paragraph;
where in the inspector’s opinion any of those matters involves or, as the case may be, will involve a contravention of any applicable provision—

P4para.Text: specify the provision or provisions in question, and
state that the inspector is of that opinion, and why.

P2para.Text: A prohibition notice takes effect—

P3para.Text: at the end of the period specified in the notice, or
if the notice so specifies, immediately.

P2para.Text: In this paragraph—

Para.Text: “applicable provision” has the same meaning as in paragraph 3;
“relevant activities” means any activities in relation to which any applicable provision applies (or would apply if they were being carried on).

P2para.Text: In this paragraph “a notice” means an improvement notice or a prohibition notice.
A notice may (but need not) include directions as to the measures to be taken to remedy any contravention or matter to which the notice relates.
Any such directions—

P3para.Text: may be expressed by reference to any approved code of practice, and
may afford the person to whom the notice is given a choice between different ways of remedying the contravention or matter.

P2para.Text: Sub-paragraph (5) applies where—

P3para.Text: any of the applicable provisions applies to a building or any matter connected with a building, and
an inspector proposes to serve an improvement notice relating to a contravention of that provision in connection with the building or matter.

P2para.Text: For this purpose “applicable provision” has the same meaning as in paragraph 3.
The notice must not direct any measures to be taken to remedy the contravention that are more onerous than any measures that would be necessary to secure conformity with—

P3para.Text: current new-build requirements, or
if the provision in question imposes specific requirements that are more onerous than the requirements of any current new-build requirements, those specific requirements.

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (5), “current new-build requirements”, in relation to a building, or matter connected with a building, means the requirements of any building regulations for the time being in force to which the building or matter would be required to conform if the relevant building were being newly erected.
In sub-paragraph (6), “building regulations”, in relation to Scotland, has the meaning given by section 1 of the Building (Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 8).
Where an improvement notice or a prohibition notice which is not to take immediate effect has been given—

P3para.Text: the notice may be withdrawn by an inspector at any time before the end of the period specified in it under paragraph 3(2) or 4(4)(a), and
the period so specified may be extended or further extended by an inspector at any time when an appeal against the notice is not pending.

P1group.Title: Appeal against improvement or prohibition notice

P2para.Text: In this paragraph, “a notice” means an improvement notice or a prohibition notice.
A person to whom a notice is given may appeal within such period after the notice is given as may be prescribed by regulations made by the Secretary of State (“the prescribed period”).
An appeal under this paragraph lies to an employment tribunal.
On an appeal, the tribunal may—

P3para.Text: cancel the notice, or
confirm it—

P4para.Text: in its original form, or
with such modifications as, in the circumstances, the tribunal considers appropriate.

P2para.Text: Where an appeal under this paragraph is brought against an improvement notice within the prescribed period, the operation of the notice is suspended until the appeal is withdrawn or finally disposed of.
Where—

P3para.Text: an appeal under this paragraph is brought against a prohibition notice within the prescribed period, and
on the application of the appellant, the tribunal, so directs,

P2para.Text: the operation of the notice is suspended from the time the direction is given until the appeal is withdrawn or finally disposed of.
One or more assessors may be appointed for the purposes of any proceedings brought before an employment tribunal under this paragraph.
It is an offence to contravene any requirement or prohibition imposed by an improvement notice or a prohibition notice.
A person who commits an offence under this paragraph is liable—

P3para.Text: on summary conviction—

P4para.Text: to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months (in England and Wales and Scotland),
to a fine not exceeding £20,000, or
to both;

P3para.Text: on conviction on indictment—

P4para.Text: to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 2 years, or
to a fine, or
to both.

P2para.Text: In relation to an offence committed before the commencement of section 154(1) of the Criminal Justice Act 2003 (general limit on magistrates’ court’s powers to imprison), the reference in sub-paragraph (2)(a)(i), as it has effect in England and Wales, to 12 months is to be read as a reference to 6 months.

Part.Title: Other powers exercisable by inspector if authorised by instrument of appointment

P2para.Text: An inspector may, if authorised, enter any premises which the inspector has reason to believe it is necessary for the inspector to enter for the relevant purpose—

P3para.Text: at any reasonable time, or
at any time, in a situation—

P4para.Text: which in the inspector’s opinion is or may be dangerous, or
in which, in the inspector’s opinion, delay would or might be prejudicial to the nuclear security purposes.

P2para.Text: In relation to domestic premises, the power may be exercised only—

P3para.Text: in accordance with a warrant issued by a justice of the peace, or
in a situation which in the inspector’s opinion is or may be dangerous.

P2para.Text: A justice of the peace may issue a warrant under sub-paragraph (2)(a) only if satisfied, on the application of the inspector,—

P3para.Text: that—

P4para.Text: there are reasonable grounds to believe that a contravention of a relevant statutory provision is occurring on the premises, or
the inspector has been refused consent to enter the premises for the relevant purpose or there are reasonable grounds to believe that such consent will be refused, and

P3para.Text: that it is reasonable in the circumstances to issue a warrant to the inspector.

P2para.Text: The reference to premises in sub-paragraph (1) includes any ship outside the United Kingdom or its territorial sea.
For the purposes of this paragraph, “domestic premises” means premises used wholly or mainly as a private dwelling.

P1group.Title: Power to take persons and equipment etc onto premises

P1para.Text: In exercising the power of entry mentioned in paragraph 8, an inspector may—

P3para.Text: be accompanied—

P4para.Text: by any person approved by the ONR for the purpose, and
if the inspector has reasonable cause to expect any serious obstruction in the exercise of any of the inspector’s powers, by a constable, and

P3para.Text: take along any equipment and materials required for any purpose for which the inspector is exercising the power of entry.

P1group.Title: Power to deal with cause of imminent danger

P2para.Text: Sub-paragraph (2) applies where an inspector finds any article or substance in relevant premises in circumstances in which the inspector has reasonable cause to believe it is a cause of imminent danger of serious personal injury.
The inspector may, if authorised, do any of the following—

P3para.Text: seize the article or substance;
cause it to be made harmless or the risk of harm from it to be reduced (in either case, by destruction or otherwise);
for the purpose mentioned in paragraph (b), seize any other article or substance.

P2para.Text: Before any article that forms part of a batch of similar articles, or any substance, is dealt with under sub-paragraph (2)(b), the inspector must, if it is practicable,—

P3para.Text: take a sample, and
give a portion of the sample, marked so as to be identifiable, to a responsible person.

P2para.Text: As soon as practicable after seizing or dealing with any article or substance under sub-paragraph (2), the inspector must make and sign a written report setting out the circumstances in which the article or substance was seized or so dealt with.
The inspector must give a signed copy of the report to a responsible person.
If that person is not the owner of the article or substance, the inspector must also—

P3para.Text: give a signed copy of the report to the owner, or
if that is not possible because—

P4para.Text: the inspector cannot find out the owner’s name or address after making reasonable enquiries, and
the owner has not indicated a willingness in accordance with section 92 to receive a signed copy of the report by any means mentioned in subsection (1)(b) of that section,

P3para.Text: give a further signed copy of the report to that responsible person.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of this paragraph—

P3para.Text: “responsible person”, in relation to any article or substance, means a responsible person at the premises in which the inspector finds the article or substance;

in the case of a report in electronic form, any signature required on the report or a copy of it may be an electronic signature (within the meaning given in section 7(2) of the Electronic Communications Act 2000).

P1group.Title: Powers exercisable in relation to particular articles or substances or in particular circumstances

P2para.Text: An authorised inspector may cause any article or substance in relevant premises—

P3para.Text: to be dismantled;
to be tested;
to have any other process applied to it.

P2para.Text: The inspector may exercise any of those powers only if it appears to the inspector—

P3para.Text: that the article or substance has caused, or is likely to cause, danger to health or safety, or
that it is desirable to do so for the nuclear security purposes.

P2para.Text: Before exercising a power in this paragraph, the inspector must consult anyone whom the inspector considers it appropriate to consult about the dangers (if any) of what is proposed.
Anything done to the article or substance under this paragraph must not damage or destroy it unless in the circumstances that is unavoidable for the relevant purpose.

If requested by a person who has responsibilities in relation to the relevant premises, and is on the premises, the inspector must allow anything done to the article or substance under this paragraph to be done in that person’s presence, unless the inspector considers that that would be prejudicial to national security.
An authorised inspector may take possession of any article or substance found on relevant premises and retain it for as long as necessary—

P3para.Text: for it to be examined;
for anything to be done to it which the inspector may cause to be done under paragraph 11;
to ensure that it is not tampered with before any examination or other procedure mentioned in paragraph (a) or (b) is complete;
to ensure that it is available for use in—

P4para.Text: any proceedings for an offence under any of the relevant statutory provisions, or
any proceedings relating to an improvement notice or a prohibition notice.

P2para.Text: The inspector may exercise that power only if it appears to the inspector—

P3para.Text: that it is desirable to do so for the nuclear security purposes, or
that the article or substance has caused, or is likely to cause, danger to health or safety.

P2para.Text: Before taking possession of any substance under this paragraph, the inspector must, if it is practicable,—

P3para.Text: take a sample of it, and
give a portion of the sample, marked so as to be identifiable, to a responsible person at the premises.

P2para.Text: An inspector who takes possession of any article or substance under this paragraph must—

P3para.Text: if it is practicable to do so, give a notice to that effect to a responsible person at the premises;
otherwise, fix such a notice in a conspicuous position at the premises.

P2para.Text: The notice must include sufficient information about the article or substance to identify it.

P1group.Title: Powers of inspection and examination and to take samples

P2para.Text: An authorised inspector may carry out any examination or investigation necessary for the relevant purpose and, in doing so, may—

P3para.Text: take measurements and photographs, and
make recordings.

P2para.Text: An authorised inspector may take and deal with samples of—

P3para.Text: any article or substance found in relevant premises, or
the atmosphere in or in the vicinity of relevant premises.

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision about—

P3para.Text: the procedure to be followed in taking any such samples, and
the way in which any such samples are to be dealt with.

P2para.Text: An authorised inspector may direct that any relevant premises, or any article or substance in them, must be left undisturbed for as long as reasonably necessary for the purposes of any examination or investigation necessary for the purpose of any of the relevant statutory provisions.
A direction under sub-paragraph (1)—

P3para.Text: may relate to part of any relevant premises;
may relate to particular aspects of any premises or article or substance.

P1group.Title: Powers to require information and documents

P2para.Text: An authorised inspector may require any person who the inspector has reasonable cause to believe is able to give any information relevant to any examination or investigation under paragraph 13—

P3para.Text: to answer any question the inspector thinks fit, and
to sign a declaration of the truth of the person’s answers.

P2para.Text: Where a person required to answer questions under this paragraph has nominated another person to be present, the person may not be required to answer questions except in the presence of the nominated person (if any).
When exercising the power in this paragraph, an inspector may allow another person to be present (in addition to the nominated person (if any)).
No answer given by a person by virtue of this paragraph is admissible in evidence against the person, or the person’s spouse or civil partner, in any proceedings.
An authorised inspector may—

P3para.Text: require any relevant documents to be produced, and
inspect and take copies of (or of any information in) any relevant documents.

P2para.Text: For this purpose—

P3para.Text: “document” includes information recorded in any form;
“relevant document” means a record or other document which—

P4para.Text: is required to be kept by virtue of any of the relevant statutory provisions, or
the inspector needs to see for the purposes of any examination or investigation under paragraph 13.

P2para.Text: In the case of a relevant document that consists of information held in electronic form, the inspector may—

P3para.Text: require it to be produced—

P4para.Text: in a legible form, or
in a form from which it can readily be produced in a legible form, and

P3para.Text: require access to, and inspect and check the operation of, any computer and any associated apparatus or material which is or has been used in connection with the relevant document.

P2para.Text: It is an offence for a person to contravene any requirement imposed by an inspector under this Part of this Schedule.
It is an offence for a person to prevent or attempt to prevent any other person from—

P3para.Text: appearing before an inspector, or
answering any question to which an inspector may require an answer by virtue of paragraph 15.

P2para.Text: A person who commits an offence under this paragraph is liable—

P3para.Text: on summary conviction—

P4para.Text: to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months (in England and Wales or Scotland) or 6 months (in Northern Ireland),
to a fine not exceeding £20,000, or
to both;

P3para.Text: on conviction on indictment—

P4para.Text: to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 2 years,
to a fine, or
to both.

P2para.Text: In relation to an offence committed before the commencement of section 154(1) of the Criminal Justice Act 2003 (general limit on magistrates’ court’s powers to imprison), the reference in sub-paragraph (3)(a)(i), as it has effect in England and Wales, to 12 months is to be read as a reference to 6 months.
It is an offence for a person intentionally to obstruct an inspector in the exercise or performance of the inspector’s functions.
A person who commits an offence under this paragraph is liable on summary conviction—

P3para.Text: to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 51 weeks (in England and Wales), 12 months (in Scotland) or 6 months (in Northern Ireland),
to a fine not exceeding level 5 on the standard scale, or
to both.

P2para.Text: In relation to an offence committed before the commencement of section 281(5) of the Criminal Justice Act 2003 (alteration of penalties for summary offences), the reference in sub-paragraph (2)(a), as it has effect in England and Wales, to 51 weeks is to be read as a reference to 6 months.
It is an offence for a person falsely to pretend to be an inspector.
A person who commits an offence under this paragraph is liable on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding level 5 on the standard scale.

P1para.Text: A power conferred by this Schedule includes power to require any person to provide any facilities or assistance relating to matters or things—

P3para.Text: within the person’s control, or
in relation to which the person has responsibilities,

P1para.Text: which are needed in order to enable an authorised inspector to exercise the power.
A power conferred by this Schedule includes power to do anything incidental that is necessary for the relevant purpose.

P1group.Title: Protection for documents subject to legal professional privilege etc

P1para.Text: Nothing in this Part of this Schedule is to be taken to confer power to compel the production by any person of a document or information in respect of which—

P3para.Text: in England and Wales or Northern Ireland, a claim to legal professional privilege, or
in Scotland, a claim to confidentiality of communications,

P1para.Text: could be maintained in legal proceedings.

P1group.Title: Duty to provide information to employees or their representatives

P2para.Text: An inspector must provide to people employed at any premises (or their representatives) any relevant information that needs to be provided in order for them (or their representatives) to be kept adequately informed about matters affecting their health, safety or welfare.
Where information is provided to employees (or their representatives) under sub-paragraph (1), the inspector must provide the same information to their employer.
For this purpose—

P3para.Text: “relevant information”, in relation to any premises, means—

P4para.Text: factual information which is protected information within the meaning of Schedule 9 and is relevant to the premises, and
information about action which the inspector has taken or proposes to take in relation to the premises, and

P3para.Text: “employee”, “employer” and “employed” have the same meanings as in Part 1 of the 1974 Act.

P2para.Text: In this Schedule—

Para.Text: “authorised” is to be read in accordance with paragraph 2(4);
“offshore installation” means any installation which is intended for underwater exploitation of mineral resources or exploration with a view to such exploitation;
“premises” includes any place and, in particular, includes—
any vehicle, ship or aircraft,

any installation on land (including the foreshore and other land intermittently covered by water), any offshore installation, and any other installation (whether floating, or resting on the seabed or its subsoil, or resting on other land covered with water or its subsoil), and
any tent or movable structure;
“relevant premises”, in relation to an inspector, means premises which the inspector has entered—
with the consent of a person who reasonably appeared to the inspector to be an appropriate person to give consent, or
in exercise of the power in paragraph 8;
“the relevant purpose”, in relation to a power, means—
if an instrument of appointment authorises the inspector to exercise the power only for limited purposes, that purpose;
in any other case, the purpose of carrying into effect the relevant statutory provisions;
“ship” includes every description of vessel used in navigation;
“substance” means any natural or artificial substance, whether solid or liquid or in the form of a gas or vapour.

P2para.Text: In this Schedule, references to an inspector, in relation to any power, are to the inspector exercising or proposing to exercise the power.

Part.Title: Prohibition on disclosure of protected information

P1group.Title: Meaning of “protected information” and related terms

P2para.Text: In this Schedule “protected information” means information which has been—

P3para.Text: obtained by the ONR under section 80,
provided to the ONR or an inspector under section 81,
obtained by an inspector as a result of the exercise of any relevant power,
obtained by a health and safety inspector in the exercise of any power under section 20 of the 1974 Act (powers of persons appointed under section 19 of that Act),
obtained by an ONR inquiry official as a result of the exercise of an ONR inquiry power,
provided to a person pursuant to a requirement imposed by any of the relevant statutory provisions, or
provided to the ONR or a health and safety inspector pursuant to a requirement imposed by any provision which is one of the relevant statutory provisions for the purposes of Part 1 of the 1974 Act.

P2para.Text: Information is not protected information for the purposes of this Schedule if it has been—

P3para.Text: disclosed as mentioned in paragraph 16, or
otherwise made available to the public—

P4para.Text: by virtue of a disclosure in accordance with Part 3 of this Schedule, or
lawfully from other sources.

P2para.Text: Information received by virtue of a disclosure under paragraph 22 (anonymised information) is not protected information.

Protected information includes, in particular, information with respect to a trade secret which an inspector, a health and safety inspector or an ONR inquiry official has obtained as a result of entering premises in exercise of a relevant power, a power conferred under section 20 of the 1974 Act or an ONR inquiry power.
In this Schedule—

Para.Text: “ONR inquiry official” means a person on whom functions are conferred under section 68(5)(a);
“ONR inquiry power” means a power conferred by regulations under under section 68(5)(a);
“the original holder” of protected information means the person who obtained the information, or to whom it was provided, as mentioned in sub-paragraph (1).

Part.Title: Offences relating to disclosure and use of protected information

P1para.Text: Protected information must not be disclosed—

P3para.Text: by the original holder of the information, or
by any other person holding it who has received it directly or indirectly from the original holder by virtue of a disclosure, or disclosures, in accordance with this Schedule,

P1para.Text: except in accordance with Part 3 of this Schedule.

P1group.Title: Offence of disclosing protected information in contravention of paragraph 2

P1para.Text: It is an offence for a person to disclose information in contravention of paragraph 2.

P1group.Title: Offence of using protected information in contravention of a restriction in Part 3

P1para.Text: It is an offence for a person to use protected information in contravention of a restriction under paragraph 10(3), 11(2), 12(2), 13(2), 14(2) or 15(2).

P1group.Title: Defence to offences under paragraph 3 and 4

P1para.Text: It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under paragraph 3 or 4 to prove—

P3para.Text: that the person did not know and had no reason to suspect that the information was protected information, or
that the person took all reasonable precautions and exercised all due diligence to avoid committing the offence.

P1group.Title: Penalty for offences under paragraph 3 and 4

P2para.Text: A person who commits an offence under paragraph 3 or 4 is liable—

P3para.Text: on summary conviction—

P4para.Text: to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months (in England and Wales or Scotland) or 6 months (in Northern Ireland),
to a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum, or
to both;

P3para.Text: on conviction on indictment—

P4para.Text: to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 2 years,
to a fine, or
to both.

P2para.Text: In the application of sub-paragraph (1) to England and Wales in relation to an offence committed before the commencement of section 154(1) of the Criminal Justice Act 2003 (general limit on magistrates’ court’s power to imprison), the reference in sub-paragraph (1)(a)(i) to 12 months is to be read as a reference to 6 months.

Part.Title: Protected information: permitted disclosures and restrictions on use

P2para.Text: Paragraph 2 does not prohibit a disclosure of protected information if it is made with the appropriate consent.
For this purpose “the appropriate consent” means—

P3para.Text: if the information was obtained as mentioned in paragraph 1(1) as a result of any premises being entered—

P4para.Text: by an inspector in exercise of a relevant power,
by a health and safety inspector in exercise of a power under section 20 of the 1974 Act, or
by an ONR inquiry official in exercise of an ONR inquiry power,

P3para.Text: the consent of a person having responsibilities in relation to the premises;
in any other case, the consent of the person from whom the information was obtained, or who provided it, as mentioned in paragraph 1(1).

P1para.Text: Paragraph 2 does not prohibit a disclosure of protected information by—

P3para.Text: the ONR,
an inspector,
a health and safety inspector, or
an ONR inquiry official,

P1para.Text: for the purposes of any of that person’s functions.

P1group.Title: Disclosure to the ONR, inspectors etc.

P1para.Text: Paragraph 2 does not prohibit a disclosure of protected information to—

P3para.Text: the ONR,
an officer of the ONR,
a person or body performing any functions of the ONR on its behalf by virtue of section 78,
an officer of such a body,
a person providing advice to the ONR,
an inspector, or
a health and safety inspector.

P1group.Title: Ministers, government departments and certain authorities

P2para.Text: Paragraph 2 does not prohibit the following disclosures of protected information—

P3para.Text: a disclosure to—

P4para.Text: a relevant authority, or
an officer of a relevant authority, or

P3para.Text: a disclosure by a person within paragraph (a) which is necessary for any of the purposes of the relevant authority in question.

P2para.Text: For this purpose, “relevant authority” means—

P3para.Text: a Minister of the Crown,
the Scottish Ministers,
the Welsh Ministers,
a Northern Ireland Department,
the Environment Agency,
the Scottish Environment Protection Agency,
the Office of Rail Regulation,
the Civil Aviation Authority, or
any other government department.

P2para.Text: A person within sub-paragraph (1)(a) to whom protected information is disclosed by virtue of any provision of this Schedule may not use the information for a purpose other than any of the purposes of the relevant authority in question.
Paragraph 2 does not prohibit the following disclosures of protected information—

P3para.Text: a disclosure to a health and safety authority, or
a disclosure by a health and safety authority which is—

P4para.Text: made by or with the consent of the Health and Safety Executive, and
necessary for any of the purposes of the Health and Safety Executive.

P2para.Text: A health and safety authority to whom protected information is disclosed by virtue of any provision of this Schedule may not use the information for any purpose other than any of the purposes of the Health and Safety Executive.
For this purpose, “health and safety authority” means—

P3para.Text: the Health and Safety Executive,
an officer of the Health and Safety Executive,
a person or body performing any functions of the Health and Safety Executive on its behalf by virtue of section 13(3) of the 1974 Act,
an officer of such a body,
an adviser appointed by that Executive under section 13(7) of that Act, and
a person appointed by that Executive under section 19 of that Act as an inspector within the meaning given in that section.

P2para.Text: Paragraph 2 does not prohibit the following disclosures of protected information—

P3para.Text: a disclosure to a person with enforcement responsibilities;
a disclosure by such a person which is—

P4para.Text: made by or with the consent of the enforcing authority in question, and
is necessary for the purposes of any function which the enforcing authority in question has in its capacity as an enforcing authority.

P2para.Text: A person with enforcement responsibilities to whom protected information is disclosed by virtue of any provision of this Schedule may not use the information otherwise than for the purposes of any function which the enforcing authority in question has in its capacity as such.
For this purpose, “person with enforcement responsibilities” means—

P3para.Text: an enforcing authority within the meaning of the 1974 Act, other than the ONR or the Health and Safety Executive;
an officer of an authority within paragraph (a);
a person appointed by such an authority under section 19 of that Act as an inspector within the meaning given in that section.

P2para.Text: Paragraph 2 does not prohibit the following disclosures of protected information—

P3para.Text: a disclosure to a Northern Ireland health and safety authority;
a disclosure by a Northern Ireland health and safety authority which is—

P4para.Text: made by or with the consent of the Health and Safety Executive for Northern Ireland, and
necessary for any of the purposes of the Health and Safety Executive for Northern Ireland.

P2para.Text: A Northern Ireland health and safety authority to whom protected information is disclosed by virtue of any provision of this Schedule may not use the information for any purpose other than any of the purposes of the Health and Safety Executive for Northern Ireland.
For this purpose, Northern Ireland health and safety authority means—

P3para.Text: the Health and Safety Executive for Northern Ireland,
an officer of the Health and Safety Executive for Northern Ireland,

a person or body performing any functions of the Health and Safety Executive for Northern Ireland on its behalf by virtue of Article 15(1)(a) of the Health and Safety at Work (Northern Ireland) Order 1978 (S.I. 1978/1039 (N.I. 9)),
an officer of such a body,
an adviser appointed by that Executive under Article 15(1)(c) of that Order, and
a person appointed by that Executive under Article 21 of that Order as an inspector within the meaning of that Article.

P1group.Title: Local authorities and water authorities etc

P2para.Text: Paragraph 2 does not prohibit the following disclosures of protected information—

P3para.Text: a disclosure by the original holder to an officer of a local authority or relevant water authority who is authorised by the authority to receive the information;
a disclosure by an officer of a local authority or relevant water authority to whom the information is disclosed by virtue of paragraph (a) which is necessary for a relevant purpose.

P2para.Text: A person to whom information is disclosed by virtue of sub-paragraph (1)(a) must not use the information for a purpose other than a relevant purpose.
For the purposes of this paragraph—

Para.Text: “local authority” includes the following—
a joint authority established by Part 4 of the Local Government Act 1985;
an authority established for an area in England by an order under section 207 of the Local Government and Public Involvement in Health Act 2007 (joint waste authorities);
an economic prosperity board established under section 88 of the Local Democracy, Economic Development and Construction Act 2009,
a combined authority established under section 103 of that Act,
the London Fire and Emergency Planning Authority;
the Broads Authority;
a National Park authority;
“relevant water authority” means—
a water undertaker,
a sewerage undertaker,
a water authority,
a water development board, or
Scottish Water;
“relevant purpose” in relation to an officer of a local authority or relevant water authority, means any purpose of the authority in connection with—
any of the relevant statutory provisions or any of the provisions which are relevant statutory provisions for the purposes of Part 1 of the 1974 Act, or
any provision of, or made under, primary legislation which relates to public health, public safety or the protection of the environment.

P2para.Text: Paragraph 2 does not prohibit the following disclosures of protected information—

P3para.Text: a disclosure by the original holder to a constable authorised by a chief officer of police to receive it;
a disclosure by a constable to whom it is disclosed by virtue of paragraph (a) which is necessary for any of the purposes of the police in connection with—

P4para.Text: the relevant statutory provisions, or
any provision of, or made under, primary legislation which relates to public health, public safety or national security.

P2para.Text: A constable to whom information is disclosed by virtue of sub-paragraph (1) must not use the information for a purpose other than a purpose of the police in connection with—

P3para.Text: any of the relevant statutory provisions or any of the provisions which are relevant statutory provisions for the purposes of Part 1 of the 1974 Act, or
any provision of, or made under, primary legislation which relates to public health, public safety or national security.

P1para.Text: Paragraph 2 does not prohibit a disclosure of protected information which is made in accordance with an obligation under—

P3para.Text: the Freedom of Information Act 2000,
the Freedom of Information (Scotland) Act 2002, or
environmental information regulations within the meaning given in section 39(1A) of the Freedom of Information Act 2000.

P1para.Text: Paragraph 2 does not prohibit a disclosure of protected information for the purposes of—

P3para.Text: any legal proceedings,
an ONR inquiry,
an inquiry under section 14(2A) of the 1974 Act which is relevant to the ONR’s purposes,
an investigation held by virtue of section 67,
any report of such proceedings, ONR inquiry or inquiry under section 14(2A) of the 1974 Act or any special report under section 67.

P1para.Text: Paragraph 2 does not prohibit a disclosure of protected information which is made—

P3para.Text: by an inspector, a health and safety inspector or an ONR inquiry official,
to a person who appears to the person making the disclosure to be likely to be a party to any civil proceedings arising out of any accident, occurrence, situation or other matter, and

in the form of a written statement of relevant facts observed by the person making the disclosure in the course of exercising a relevant power, a power under section 20 of the 1974 Act or an ONR inquiry power.

P1para.Text: Paragraph 2 does not prohibit a disclosure of protected information which is made—

P3para.Text: by the ONR, an inspector, a health and safety inspector or an ONR inquiry official, and
for any of the purposes specified in section 17(2)(a) to (d) of the Anti-terrorism, Crime and Security Act 2001 (criminal proceedings and investigations).

P1para.Text: Section 18 of that Act (restriction on disclosure of information for overseas purposes) has effect in relation to a disclosure authorised by sub-paragraph (1) as it has effect in relation to a disclosure authorised by any of the provisions to which section 17 of that Act applies.
Paragraph 2 does not prohibit a disclosure of protected information which is made for the purposes of any of the safeguards obligations.
Paragraph 2 does not prohibit a disclosure of protected information which is made in a form calculated to prevent the information from being identified as relating to a particular person or case.
The prohibition in paragraph 2 is to be disregarded for the purposes of—

P3para.Text: section 44 of the Freedom of Information Act 2000, and
section 26 of the Freedom of Information (Scotland) Act 2002,

P1para.Text: (which provide for exemptions from disclosure requirements under those Acts for information subject to statutory prohibitions on disclosure).

Nothing in this Part of this Act is to be taken to permit or require a disclosure of information which is prohibited by or under any provision of primary legislation (including, in particular, section 79 or 80 of the Anti-terrorism, Crime and Security Act 2001 (prohibition on disclosure of information relating to nuclear security)).
In this Schedule—

Para.Text: “offence” means an offence created by or under a relevant provision;
“relevant provision” means any of the relevant statutory provisions other than any provision made by or under the Nuclear Safeguards Act 2000.

P2para.Text: If an offence is committed in connection with any plant or substance, the offence may be treated as having been committed at the place where the plant or substance is for the time being.
Sub-paragraph (1) applies only if it is necessary to treat the offence as having been committed there for the purpose of conferring jurisdiction on any court to entertain proceedings for the offence.
In this paragraph—

Para.Text: “plant” includes any machinery, equipment or appliance;
“substance” means any natural or artificial substance, whether in solid or liquid form or in the form of a gas or vapour.

P2para.Text: This paragraph is subject to any provision made in nuclear regulations by virtue of section 58(5)(b) (treatment of offences as having been committed at a specified place).

P1group.Title: Extension of time for bringing summary proceedings

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies where—

P3para.Text: a special report on a matter is made under section 67(1);
a report is made by a person holding an ONR inquiry;
a coroner’s inquest is held into a relevant death; or
a public inquiry under the Fatal Accidents and Sudden Deaths Inquiry (Scotland) Act 1976 is held into a relevant death.

P2para.Text: A “relevant death” is the death of any person which may have been caused—

P3para.Text: by an accident which happened while at work,
by a disease which the person contracted (or probably contracted) while at work, or
by an accident, act or omission which occurred in connection with the work of any person.

P2para.Text: Sub-paragraph (4) applies if it appears from—

P3para.Text: the report mentioned in sub-paragraph (1)(a) or (b),
the inquest mentioned in sub-paragraph (1)(c), or
the proceedings at the inquiry mentioned in sub-paragraph (1)(d),

P2para.Text: that a relevant provision was contravened at a time which is material in relation to the subject-matter of the report, inquest or inquiry.
Summary proceedings against any person liable to be proceeded against in respect of the contravention may be commenced at any time within 3 months of—

P3para.Text: the making of the report in question, or
(as the case may be) the conclusion of the inquest or inquiry.

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies to any offence that a person commits as a result of a provision or requirement that the person is subject to as the designer, manufacturer, importer or supplier of any thing.
Summary proceedings for the offence may be commenced at any time within 6 months from the date on which there comes to the knowledge of the ONR evidence that appears sufficient to the ONR—

P3para.Text: to justify a prosecution for the offence, or
in relation to an offence in Scotland, to justify a report to the Lord Advocate with a view to consideration of the question for prosecution.

P2para.Text: For this purpose—

P3para.Text: a certificate of the ONR stating that such evidence came to its knowledge on a specified date is to be taken as conclusive evidence of that fact,
a document purporting to be such a certificate, and to be signed on behalf of the ONR, is to be presumed to be such a certificate unless the contrary is proved, and
in relation to an offence in Scotland, section 136(3) of the Criminal Procedure (Scotland) Act 1995 (date of commencement of proceedings) has effect as it has effect for the purposes of that section.

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies where an offence is committed as a result of a failure to do something at or within a time fixed by or under a relevant provision.
The offence is to be deemed to continue until the thing is done.

P1group.Title: Offences due to fault of other person

P2para.Text: A person (“A”) is guilty of an offence if—

P3para.Text: another person (“B”) commits the offence, and
B’s commission of the offence is due to the act or default of A,

P2para.Text: and A is liable to be proceeded against and dealt with accordingly.
For this purpose it does not matter whether or not proceedings are taken against B.
A person (“A”) is guilty of an offence if—

P3para.Text: A is a person other than the Crown,
the offence would have been committed by the Crown but for the fact that the provision under which the offence is committed does not bind the Crown, and
the Crown’s commission of the offence would have been due to the act or default of A,

P2para.Text: and A is liable to be proceeded against and dealt with accordingly.
This paragraph is subject to any provision made in nuclear regulations.
Where an offence committed by a body corporate is proved—

P3para.Text: to have been committed with the consent or connivance of an officer of the body corporate, or
to be attributable to neglect on the part of an officer of the body corporate,

P2para.Text: that officer (as well as the body corporate) is guilty of the offence and is liable to be proceeded against and dealt with accordingly.
In sub-paragraph (1) “officer”, in relation to a body corporate, means—

P3para.Text: any director, manager, secretary or other similar officer of the body corporate, or
any person purporting to act in any such capacity.

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (2) “director”, in relation to a body corporate whose affairs are managed by its members, means a member of the body corporate.
Proceedings for an offence alleged to have been committed by a partnership may be brought in the name of the partnership.
Rules of court relating to the service of documents have effect in relation to proceedings for an offence as if the partnership were a body corporate.
For the purposes of such proceedings the following provisions apply as they apply in relation to a body corporate—

P3para.Text: section 33 of the Criminal Justice Act 1925 and Schedule 3 to the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980, and
section 18 of the Criminal Justice Act (Northern Ireland) 1945 and Schedule 4 to the Magistrates’ Courts (Northern Ireland) Order 1981.

P2para.Text: A fine imposed on a partnership on its conviction for an offence is to be paid out of the partnership assets.
Where an offence committed by a partnership is proved—

P3para.Text: to have been committed with the consent or connivance of a partner, or
to be attributable to neglect on the part of a partner,

P2para.Text: the partner (as well as the partnership) is guilty of the offence and is liable to be proceeded against and dealt with accordingly.
In this paragraph “partner” includes a person purporting to act as a partner.

P1group.Title: Restriction on institution of proceedings in England and Wales

P1para.Text: Proceedings for an offence in England and Wales may only be instituted—

P3para.Text: by the ONR or an inspector, or
by, or with the consent of, the Director of Public Prosecutions.

P1group.Title: Prosecutions by inspectors in England and Wales

P1para.Text: An inspector may prosecute proceedings for an offence before a magistrates’ court in England and Wales if authorised to do so by the inspector’s instrument of appointment (see paragraph 2 of Schedule 8).

P1group.Title: Onus of proving limits of what is practicable etc

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies if regulations under this Part create an offence consisting of—

P3para.Text: a failure to comply with a duty or requirement to do something so far as practicable (or reasonably practicable), or
a failure to use the best means do something.

P2para.Text: The regulations may provide that it is for the defendant to prove that—

P3para.Text: it was not practicable (or reasonably practicable) to do more than was in fact done to satisfy the duty or requirement, or
there was no better practicable means than was in fact used to satisfy the duty or requirement.

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies where a requirement is imposed by a relevant provision for an entry to be made in any register or other record.
If the entry is made, it is—

P3para.Text: admissible in evidence, or
in Scotland, sufficient evidence of the facts stated in the entry,

P2para.Text: against the person by or on whose behalf the entry is made.
If the entry is not made, and the requirement relates to making the entry in respect of observance with a relevant provision, the fact that the entry is not made—

P3para.Text: is admissible in evidence, or
in Scotland, sufficient evidence that the provision has not been observed.

P1group.Title: Power of court to order cause of offence to be remedied

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies where—

P3para.Text: a person (“P”) is convicted of an offence, and
it appears to the court that the matters in respect of which P is convicted are matters that are within P’s power to remedy.

P2para.Text: The court may (in addition to, or instead of, imposing any punishment) order P to take such steps as the order may specify for the purpose of remedying those matters.
The steps are to be taken within such time as may be fixed by the order (“the remedial period”).
The court may extend or further extend the remedial period on an application.
An application under sub-paragraph (4) must be made—

P3para.Text: before the end of the remedial period, or
before the end of that period as extended on a previous application.

P2para.Text: Where P is ordered to remedy any matters by an order under this paragraph—

P3para.Text: it is an offence for P to fail to comply with the order, but
P is not liable under any relevant provision in respect of those matters to the extent that they continue during—

P4para.Text: the remedial period, or
any extension of that period granted under sub-paragraph (4).

P2para.Text: A person who commits an offence under this paragraph is liable—

P3para.Text: on summary conviction—

P4para.Text: to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months (in England and Wales or Scotland) or 6 months (in Northern Ireland),
to a fine not exceeding £20,000, or
to both;

P3para.Text: on conviction on indictment—

P4para.Text: to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 2 years,
to a fine, or
to both.

P2para.Text: In the application of sub-paragraph (7) to England and Wales in relation to an offence committed before the commencement of section 154(1) of the Criminal Justice Act 2003 (general limit on magistrates’ court’s powers to imprison), the reference in sub-paragraph (7)(a)(i) to 12 months is to be read as a reference to 6 months.

TitleBlock.Title: Transfers to the Office for Nuclear Regulation

P1para.Text: In this Schedule—

Para.Text: “the HSE” means the Health and Safety Executive;
“the interim ONR” means the agency of the HSE currently known as the Office for Nuclear Regulation;
“TUPE regulations” means the Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) Regulations 2006 (S.I. 2006/246).

P1group.Title: Power to make staff transfer schemes

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may make one or more schemes under which an employee to whom the scheme applies becomes an employee of the ONR (but this is subject to provision contained in the scheme by virtue of paragraph 6).
A scheme under sub-paragraph (1) is referred to in this Schedule as a “staff transfer scheme”.

P1group.Title: Staff to whom a transfer may apply

P2para.Text: The employees to whom a transfer scheme may apply are those employees who fall within sub-paragraph (2).
An employee falls within this sub-paragraph if, immediately before the staff transfer scheme takes effect, the employee—

P3para.Text: was employed by the HSE under a contract of employment, and
was assigned to work in the interim ONR.

P2para.Text: Sub-paragraph (4) applies for the purposes of determining whether an employee was assigned as mentioned in sub-paragraph (2) where, immediately before the transfer scheme takes effect, the employee—

P3para.Text: is on secondment,
is temporarily assigned to work in another part of the HSE, or
is otherwise temporarily absent.

P2para.Text: That sub-paragraph is to be read as if it operated immediately before the date of the secondment or temporary assignment, or the date when the absence began, instead of immediately before the date on which the scheme takes effect.

P1group.Title: Content of a staff transfer scheme

P2para.Text: A staff transfer scheme may make provision for giving full effect to an employee’s transfer into the employment of the ONR as a result of the scheme.
Provision made by virtue of sub-paragraph (1) may include provision—

P3para.Text: that has the same or similar effect as the TUPE regulations (so far as those regulations do not apply in relation to the transfer);
modifying the law (including provision made by an Act or subordinate legislation) applicable to the employee’s employment;
about the pension entitlements of the employee enjoyed immediately before the transfer.

P2para.Text: A staff transfer scheme may apply to all, or to any specified class or description of, the employees falling within paragraph 4(2) or to specified employees so falling.
“Specified” means specified in the scheme.

A staff transfer scheme may make provision enabling an employee to object to the transfer which would otherwise be effected by the scheme including provision as to how such an objection is to be made and as to the consequences of it.

A staff transfer scheme may make provision allowing an employee to be treated as being temporarily assigned to the ONR for a period limited by the scheme, whether at the employee’s election or in the exercise of a discretion conferred on the Secretary of State by the scheme.
Provision made by virtue of sub-paragraph (2) may include provision—

P3para.Text: allowing the employee to elect to end the period of temporary assignment by agreeing to become an employee of the ONR or by objecting to the transfer under sub-paragraph (1);
as to the consequences of the expiry of the period of temporary assignment without such an election having been made;
as to the employee’s pay (and the liability to pay it) and the terms and conditions on which the employee is engaged.

P1group.Title: Power to make property transfer schemes

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may make one or more schemes transferring qualifying property, rights and liabilities of the HSE to the ONR.
The Secretary of State may make one or more schemes transferring qualifying property, rights and liabilities of the Secretary of State to the ONR.
A scheme under sub-paragraph (1) or (2) is referred to in this Schedule as a “property transfer scheme”.

P1para.Text: The HSE may submit to the Secretary of State proposals about the exercise of the power to make property transfer schemes.

P2para.Text: References in this Part to “qualifying property, rights and liabilities” are to property held, and rights and liabilities arising, in connection with—

P3para.Text: functions under any enactment which were functions of the Secretary of State or the HSE and as a result of this Act have or are to become functions of the ONR;
functions which were functions of the Secretary of State or the HSE which have been or are to be replaced by a function of the ONR under this Act;
functions which were carried out by the HSE under an agreement under section 13 of the 1974 Act and which are to be carried out by ONR under an agreement under section 73.

P2para.Text: Rights and liabilities arising under or in connection with a contract of employment in effect when the scheme comes into force are excluded from the rights and liabilities which may be transferred under a property transfer scheme.

P1group.Title: Content of a property transfer scheme

P2para.Text: A property transfer scheme may, in particular, make provision—

P3para.Text: for anything done by or in relation to the HSE or the Secretary of State in connection with any property, rights or liabilities transferred by the scheme to be treated as done, or to be continued, by or in relation to the ONR;

for references to the HSE or the Secretary of State in any agreement (whether written or not), instrument or other document relating to any property, rights or liabilities transferred by the scheme to be treated as references to the ONR;
about the continuation of legal proceedings;
for transferring property, rights or liabilities which could not otherwise be transferred or assigned;
for transferring property, rights and liabilities irrespective of any requirement for consent which would otherwise apply;

for preventing a right of pre-emption, right of reverter, right of forfeiture, right to compensation or other similar right from arising or becoming exercisable as a result of the transfer of property, rights or liabilities;
for dispensing with any formality in relation to the transfer of property, rights or liabilities by the scheme
for transferring property acquired, or rights or liabilities arising, after the scheme is made but before it takes effect;
for apportioning property, rights or liabilities;
for creating rights, or imposing liabilities, in connection with property, rights or liabilities transferred by the scheme;
for requiring the ONR to enter into any agreement of any kind, or for a purpose, specified in or determined in accordance with the scheme.

P2para.Text: Sub-paragraph (1)(b) does not apply to references in primary legislation or in subordinate legislation.
In this Part “property” includes interests of any description.

P1para.Text: A scheme may contain provision for the payment of compensation by the Secretary of State to any person whose interests are adversely affected by it.

Part.Title: Procedure for making or modifying schemes under this Schedule

P2para.Text: Before making a staff transfer scheme or a property transfer scheme, the Secretary of State must be satisfied that—

P3para.Text: those persons that the Secretary of State considers likely to be affected by the making of the scheme, and
such other persons as appear to the Secretary of State to represent the interests of such persons,

P2para.Text: have been consulted (whether by the Secretary of State or another person) and must have regard to the results of the consultation in determining whether to make the scheme.
Sub-paragraph (3) applies where—

P3para.Text: the Secretary of State is proposing to make a modification to a staff transfer scheme or a property transfer scheme under section 132,
it appears to the Secretary of State that the modification is likely to have a material effect on any person, and
the Secretary of State is not required under subsection (3) of that section to obtain the agreement of those persons before making the modification.

P2para.Text: Before making the modification, the Secretary of State must be satisfied that—

P3para.Text: any person or persons falling within sub-paragraph (2)(b), and
such other persons as appear to the Secretary of State to represent the interests of such persons,

P2para.Text: have been consulted (whether by the Secretary of State or another person) and must have regard to the results of the consultation in determining whether to make the modification.
For the purposes of this paragraph it does not matter whether consultation takes place before or after the passing of this Act.

TitleBlock.Title: Minor and consequential amendments relating to Part 3

Part.Title: Amendments of the Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974

P1group.Title: Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974 (c.37)

P1para.Text: The Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974 is amended as follows.

P2para.Text: Section 11 (functions of the Health and Safety Executive) is amended as follows.
In subsection (4)—

P3para.Text: in paragraph (a), for “the railway safety purposes” substitute “any of the transferred purposes”, and
in paragraph (b), for the words following “made” substitute

P4para.Text: for any of the transferred purposes, or
under section 43 and concern fees relating to nuclear site regulation.

P2para.Text: After that subsection insert—
In subsection (4)—

P3para.Text: “the transferred purposes” means—

P4para.Text: the railway safety purposes;
the nuclear safety purposes;
the nuclear security purposes;
the nuclear safeguards purposes;
the radioactive material transport purposes;

P3para.Text: “fees relating to nuclear site regulation” means fees payable for or in connection with the performance of a function by or on behalf of—

P4para.Text: the Office for Nuclear Regulation, or
any inspector appointed by the Office for Nuclear Regulation.

P2para.Text: The Executive may submit to the Secretary of State any proposal submitted to it by the Office for Nuclear Regulation under section 64 of the Energy Act 2013 (proposals about orders and regulations).

P1para.Text: In section 13 (powers of the Executive), after subsection (6) insert—

P2para.Text: The reference in subsection (6) to the general purposes of this Part does not include a reference to any of the following—

P3para.Text: the nuclear safety purposes;
the nuclear security purposes;
the nuclear safeguards purposes;
the radioactive material transport purposes.

P2para.Text: Section 14 (power of the Executive to direct investigations and inquiries) is amended as follows.
In subsection (1)(a), after “railway safety purposes” insert “or the ONR’s purposes”.
After subsection (4) insert—

Provision that may be made by virtue of subsection (4)(a) includes in particular, provision conferring functions on the Office for Nuclear Regulation in relation to powers of entry and inspection in relation to any premises for which it is an enforcing authority.
Section 15 (health and safety regulations) is amended as follows.
After subsection (1) insert—
In subsection (1), the reference to the general purposes of this Part does not include a reference to any of the following—

P3para.Text: the nuclear safety purposes;
the nuclear security purposes;
the nuclear safeguards purposes;
the radioactive material transport purposes.

P2para.Text: Subsection (1A) does not preclude health and safety regulations from including provision merely because the provision could be made for any of the purposes mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d) of that subsection.
In subsection (2), for “the preceding subsection” substitute “subsection (1)”.
In subsection (3)(c), after “may” insert “, subject to subsection (3A),”.
After subsection (3) insert—

Nothing in this section is to be taken to permit health and safety regulations to make provision about responsibility for the enforcement of any of the relevant statutory provisions as they apply in relation to any GB nuclear site.

Subsection (3A) does not prevent health and safety regulations providing for the Office of Rail Regulation to be responsible for the enforcement, in relation to GB nuclear sites, of any of the relevant statutory provisions that are made for the railway safety purposes.
In subsections (3A) and (3B), “GB nuclear site” has the same meaning as in section 52 of the Energy Act 2013 (nuclear safety purposes).
Section 18 (authorities responsible for enforcement of the relevant statutory provisions) is amended as follows.
After subsection (1) insert—

The Office for Nuclear Regulation is responsible for the enforcement of the relevant statutory provisions as they apply in relation to GB nuclear sites (within the meaning given in section 52 of the Energy Act 2013 (nuclear safety purposes)).

Subsection (1A) is subject to any provision of health and safety regulations making the Office of Rail Regulation responsible for the enforcement of any of the relevant statutory provisions to any extent in relation to such sites.
In subsection (2)—

P3para.Text: before paragraph (a) insert—

make the Office for Nuclear Regulation responsible for the enforcement of the relevant statutory provisions to such extent as may be prescribed (and may in particular provide for any site or matter in relation to which the Office for Nuclear Regulation is made so responsible to be determined by the Secretary of State or the Office for Nuclear Regulation under the regulations);
in paragraph (b), before sub-paragraph (i) insert—

P4para.Text: transferred from the Executive or local authorities to the Office for Nuclear Regulation, or from the Office for Nuclear Regulation to the Executive or local authorities;

P3para.Text: in paragraph (b)(ii)—

P4para.Text: after “Executive” insert “, to the Office for Nuclear Regulation”;
after “by virtue of” insert “subsection (1A) or”;

P3para.Text: in paragraph (b), after sub-paragraph (ii) insert—

P5para.Text: assigned to the Office of Rail Regulation or the Office for Nuclear Regulation for the purpose of removing any uncertainty as to what are by virtue of any of the relevant statutory provisions their respective responsibilities for the enforcement of any of those provisions;

P2para.Text: After subsection (3) insert—
Regulations under subsection (2)(a) may not make local authorities enforcing authorities in relation to any site in relation to which the Office for Nuclear Regulation is an enforcing authority.

Where the Office for Nuclear Regulation is, by or under subsection (1A) or (2), made responsible for the enforcement of any of the relevant statutory provisions to any extent, it must make adequate arrangements for the enforcement of those provisions to that extent.
In subsection (5) in the opening words, after “the Executive” insert “, the Office for Nuclear Regulation”.
In subsection (7), in the words following paragraph (b)—

P3para.Text: after “section 13” insert “of this Act or section 78 of the Energy Act 2013 (power for Office for Nuclear Regulation to arrange for exercise of functions by others)”;
after “the Executive” (in the first and third places) insert “or the Office for Nuclear Regulation”;
after “the Executive” (in the second place) insert “or the Office for Nuclear Regulation (as the case may be)”;
for “under that subsection” substitute “or arrangements under the provision in question”.

P1para.Text: In section 27 (obtaining of information by the Executive, enforcing authorities etc), in subsection (1)(b), after “an enforcing authority” insert “other than the Office for Nuclear Regulation”.

In section 27A (information communicated by Commissioners for Revenue and Customs), in subsection (2), at the end insert “, other than the Office for Nuclear Regulation or an inspector appointed by the Office for Nuclear Regulation”.

P2para.Text: Section 28 (restrictions on disclosure of information) is amended as follows.
In subsection (1)(a), after “to any person” insert “, other than the Office for Nuclear Regulation (or an inspector appointed by it),”.
In subsection (3)(a), after “Executive” insert “, the Office for Nuclear Regulation,”.
In subsection (4)—

P3para.Text: in the opening words—

P4para.Text: after “Executive” (in the first place), insert “, the Office for Nuclear Regulation,”;
after “Executive” (in the second place), insert “or the Office for Nuclear Regulation”;

P3para.Text: in paragraph (a), after “Executive” insert “or Office for Nuclear Regulation” and after “section 13(3)” insert “of this Act or, as the case may be, section 78 of the Energy Act 2013”;
in paragraph (c), at the end insert “or, in the case of the Office for Nuclear Regulation, a person providing advice to that body.”.

P2para.Text: In subsection (5)(a), after “Executive” insert “, of the Office for Nuclear Regulation”.
After subsection (9A) insert—
Nothing in subsection (7) or (9) applies to a person appointed as an inspector by the Office for Nuclear Regulation in relation to functions which the person has by virtue of that appointment.
Section 44 (appeals in connection with licensing provisions in the relevant statutory provisions) is amended as follows.
In subsection (1), omit “(other than nuclear site licences”).
In subsection (7)—

P3para.Text: in paragraph (a) omit “other than a nuclear site licence”;
omit paragraph (b).

P2para.Text: Omit subsection (8).
Section 50 (regulations under the relevant statutory provisions) is amended as follows.
In subsection (1AA), for the words following “unless” substitute “the Secretary of State has consulted—

P3para.Text: the Executive,
the Office for Nuclear Regulation, and
such other bodies as appear to the Secretary of State to be appropriate.

P2para.Text: In subsection (2), for “the Executive” substitute

P3para.Text: the Executive, and
the Office for Nuclear Regulation.

P2para.Text: In subsection (3), before paragraph (a) insert—
